factoid: Prince Andrew arrived at Grunth between three and four o’clock in the afternoon.
Prince Andrew had persisted in his request to Kutúzov.
Prince Andrew reported himself to Bagratión at Grunth.
Bonaparte’s adjutant had not yet reached Murat’s detachment.
The battle had not yet begun.
No one in Bagratión’s detachment knew the general position of affairs.
Some people in Bagratión’s detachment talked of peace but did not believe it was possible.
Others in Bagratión’s detachment talked of a battle but disbelieved an engagement would be near.
Bagratión knew that Bolkónski was a favorite and trusted adjutant.
Bagratión received Bolkónski with distinction and special marks of favor.
Bagratión explained to Bolkónski that there would probably be an engagement that day or the next.
Bagratión gave Bolkónski full liberty to remain with him during the battle or to join the rearguard and observe the order of retreat.
Bagratión told Prince Andrew that there would hardly be an engagement today.
Bagratión thought that if Bolkónski were an ordinary staff dandy he could earn a medal in the rearguard, but if he wished to stay with Bagratión he would be useful if he were a brave officer.
Prince Andrew asked for permission to ride around the position to see the disposition of the forces so that he would know his bearings if he were sent to execute an order.
The officer on duty was a handsome, elegantly dressed man with a diamond ring on his forefinger.
The officer on duty was fond of speaking French, though he spoke it badly.
The officer on duty offered to conduct Prince Andrew.
They saw rain‑soaked officers with dejected faces who seemed to be seeking something.
They saw soldiers dragging doors, benches, and fencing from the village.
The staff officer said, "There now, Prince! We can’t stop those fellows."
The staff officer pointed to the soldiers and said, "The officers don’t keep them in hand."
The staff officer pointed to a sutler’s tent and said, "They crowd in and sit."
The staff officer said, "This morning I turned them all out and now look, it’s full again."
The staff officer said, "I must go there, Prince, and scare them a bit."
Prince Andrew said, "Yes, let’s go in and I will get myself a roll and some cheese."
Prince Andrew had not yet had time to eat anything.
The staff officer asked Prince Andrew why he had not mentioned it, saying, "I would have offered you something."
They dismounted and entered the tent.
Several officers with flushed and weary faces were sitting at the table eating and drinking.
The staff officer asked, "Now what does this mean, gentlemen?" in a reproachful tone.
The staff officer said, "You know it won’t do to leave your posts like this."
The staff officer said, "The prince gave orders that no one should leave his post."
The staff officer turned to a thin, dirty little artillery officer without his boots, who had given them to the canteen keeper to dry, and who was in only his stockings.
The artillery officer rose when they entered, smiling not altogether comfortably.
The staff officer said, "Well aren’t you ashamed of yourself, Captain Túshin?"
The staff officer said, "One would think that as an artillery officer you would set a good example, yet here you are without your boots!"
The staff officer said, "The alarm will be sounded and you’ll be in a pretty position without your boots!"
The staff officer smiled.
The staff officer said, "Kindly return to your posts… all of you… all!"
Prince Andrew smiled involuntarily as he looked at the artillery officer Túshin.
Captain Túshin was silent and smiling, shifting from one stocking foot to the other, glancing inquiringly with his large, intelligent, kind eyes from Prince Andrew to the staff officer.
Captain Túshin said, "The soldiers say it feels easier without boots," smiling shyly.
Captain Túshin was in an uncomfortable position.
Captain Túshin wished to adopt a jocular tone.
Captain Túshin felt his jest was unacceptable and had not come off.
Captain Túshin grew confused.
The staff officer said, "Kindly return to your posts," trying to preserve his gravity.
Prince Andrew glanced again at the artillery officer’s small figure.
There was something peculiar about the artillery officer’s small figure, quite unsoldierly, rather comic, but extremely attractive.
The staff officer and Prince Andrew mounted their horses and rode on.
